trails.name: Balanced Rock Trail
trails.description: Iconic rock formations on the East Bluff

trails.name: East Bluff Trail
trails.description: Challenging climb with spectacular lake views

trails.name: West Bluff Trail
trails.description: Rugged trail along the western bluffs

trails.name: Ice Age National Scenic Trail - Devil's Lake Segment
trails.description: Part of the 1,200-mile Ice Age Trail

trails.name: Parfrey's Glen Trail
trails.description: Wisconsin's first State Natural Area

trails.name: Devil's Lake State Park
trails.description: The park also has 8.0 miles of off-road bike trails-the Upland Trail Loop and the connector between Steinke Basin and the north shore picnic area. Trails open to bikers are so posted. A state trail pass is not required to use the mountain bike trails. Bicyclists must use caution and give hikers the right-of-way.

trails.name: Devils Lake State Park
trails.description:
Hilly, rocky, rooty, some gravel, mostly doubletrack. Lots of elevation gain and
loss. Bring your climbing legs!

trails.name: Devil's Head
trails.description:
Excellent Singletrack on every trail.










few $ at hotel registration
2 loopsDylabob,Goast Rock get on top of the ski slopes for these, 5 other trails on the woods, Deer Run longest down hill along Bluff rd.  look for 2 new trails(2003)off Mid Mtn.   Bring the WATER

trails.name: Dam Trails at Alliant Energy
trails.description: There are between 3 and 3.5 miles of trail built out; a nice mix of fast-drying sand and interesting terrain, with more being built all the time. Check out https://www.madcitydirt.com/index.php?topic=4304.0

trails.name: Mirror Lake S.p. Fern Dell Loop
trails.description: Good beginner trail with some loose sand and some hills.

trails.name: Mirror Lake State Park
trails.description: There are about nine miles of trails available for off-road bike enthusiasts.

trails.name: Eagle Trail
trails.description: Blufftop trail with stunning bay views

trails.name: Sentinel Trail
trails.description: Trail to historic observation tower

trails.name: Skyline Trail
trails.description: Ridge trail connecting park features

trails.name: Peninsula State Park
trails.description:
Within the center of the park there is 12 miles of unsurfaced trails including a singletrack loop and other 
mountain bike trails of easy to moderate difficulty.

trails.name: Lost Canyon Trail
trails.description: Explore sandstone canyons and caves

trails.name: Stephens Falls Trail
trails.description: Short walk to picturesque waterfall

trails.name: Mill Creek Trail
trails.description: Longest loop in the park

trails.name: Governor Dodge State Park
trails.description:
Fast doubletrack with lots of hills. Mostly grassy mowed trail, some roots, rocks gravel and sand. A large loop and a small loop that form a figure 8. My wife loves this trail because it offers a good aerobic workout without being too technically challenging. Good for novices, but they may end up walking up some of the hills.

WI State Park pass required. WI State Trail pass required.

trails.name: Koehler-andre Black River Trail
trails.description: This trail is in a State Park, so fees will apply (daily sticker or annual sticker). The park website suggests "area contains open field community and forested areas".

trails.name: Evergreen Park
trails.description: A variety of single and double track allows racers to test their skills over picturesque flowing technical trails. Terrain including grass, mud, asphalt, gravel, sand, "Sheboygan Slickrock", roots, rocks, and the "Equalizer" add to the fun.

trails.name: Mirror Lake State Park
trails.description: There are about nine miles of trails available for off-road bike enthusiasts.

trails.name: Mirror Lake S.p. Fern Dell Loop
trails.description: Good beginner trail with some loose sand and some hills.

trails.name: Devil's Lake State Park
trails.description: The park also has 8.0 miles of off-road bike trails-the Upland Trail Loop and the connector between Steinke Basin and the north shore picnic area. Trails open to bikers are so posted. A state trail pass is not required to use the mountain bike trails. Bicyclists must use caution and give hikers the right-of-way.

trails.name: Devils Lake State Park
trails.description:
Hilly, rocky, rooty, some gravel, mostly doubletrack. Lots of elevation gain and
loss. Bring your climbing legs!

trails.name: Wyalusing State Park
trails.description: Wyalusing's two mountain bike trails (Whitetail Meadows and Mississippi Ridge) are not designed for high speed travel. They can become soft and slippery when wet, and can erode quickly during heavy rains. Remember, hikers have the right of way.

trails.name: Whitetail Meadows Trail
trails.description: Whitetail Meadows Trail is a doubletrack ski trail loop that skirts the edge of a meadow and a hardwood forest. It serves as a great ride for the whole family during a trip to the state park, but don't expect any technical elements.

trails.name: Pleasure Valley Trail
trails.description: Pleasure Valley Trail is a nice doubletrack warm-up for the aerobically and technically challenging singletrack at Blue Mound. The trail starts with a steep and blazingly fast bomb down the mountain until you get to the loop. Then it undulates until you make it back to the start of the loop and the climb back to the parking lot. Remember that this trail is very popular with hikers, so control your speed.

trails.name: Blue Mound State Park
trails.description: The park has 15.5 miles of challenging off-road, singletrack bicycle trails. A state trail pass is required of all bicyclists aged 16 and over (in addition to the vehicle admission sticker). Trails are open spring, summer and fall unless wet trail conditions exist. Trails are closed during winter.

kettle-moraine-south.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Southern Unit

trails.name: Ice Age Trail - Lapham Peak Segment
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Southern Unit
trails.description: Glacial terrain on the Ice Age Trail

trails.name: Nordic Ski Trails
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Southern Unit
trails.description: Multi-use trail system through kettle terrain

trails.name: Kettle Moraine John Muir + Emma Carlin
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Southern Unit
trails.description:
There are many different loops with many different options for rides. Ranging from a 4 mile ride, to this 28 mile ride which took
3.75hrs. The terrain ranges from rolling singletrack, to very technical rocky sections. Very tough climbs and some screaming
downhills. From meadows, dense forest, to pine stands with sandy soil. Its a great 'all-mountain' feel from the Midwest. definitely
a gem for the area. There is the southwester section called the John Muir trails which runs only clockwise for mountain bikers. It
has a few cheater lines so this section can be as short as 4 miles, or up to 8 or so. Great facilities in the lot. From the northern
corner, there is an offshoot which can guide you to the connector trail. This trail itself is a 6 mile ride over to the Emma Carlin trail
loop. This connector and the Emma Carlin trail system are a bit more wild and feel more detached- which make it much more
demanding. One could also park at the Emma Carlin TH parking lot which is up further north.

Link here: http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?
msid=213180165457512089236.000446d5627557a673b6c&msa=0&iwloc=000446d58c1632cb7475c

trails.name: John Muir Trails
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Southern Unit
trails.description: These are great single track trails located in a state forest. Some technical parts, but most riders will be able to find a track that suites them. They are a series of loops, with a ten-mile track being the longest. There is also a five mile connector trail that connects to another series of trails - the Emma Carlin trails. Considering the area, these are the best trails for single track riding in this area of the state!

kettle-moraine-north.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit

trails.name: Zillmer Trail
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit
trails.description: Challenging terrain through glacial landscape

trails.name: Greenbush Trail
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit
trails.description: Historic area with varied terrain

trails.name: New Fane
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit
trails.description: Just finished for 2010.  Singletrack, singletrack, singletrack.  Fun for all abilities.   This used to be all doubletrack shared with hikers, now double track is hikers only and singletrack is for bikers.  Classic north kettle wisconsin forested mountain biking.  AFter living out west I really love this stuff, there you are either grunting up an uphill or riding the brakes downhill... loving me the rolling flats!

trails.name: Kettle Moraine State Forest
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit
trails.description: Single-track mountain bike trails are maintained at the Greenbush recreation area (9 miles) and New Fane recreation area (5.5 miles).

trails.name: Glacial Blue Hills
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit
trails.description: Porta-potty and bike repair stand located in the parking lot. Technical, rocky, and rooty old school singletrack. Lots of climbing. Follow the orange trail markers to Headbangers Flow Trail with table top jump. Be sure to check out the south side trails - you'll find the best flow if you ride them counter clockwise. New flow trail coming summer 2023.

trails.name: Lake to Lake
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit
trails.description: A double track that connects two great state recreation areas in the heart of the beautiful Northern Kettle Moraine State Forest. Very easy doubletrack with several areas of nice flow. Great place to get out and ride and see some of the best scenery that Wisconsin has to offer. Also a great place to take beginner riders to help introduce them to bike riding. Unlike neighboring New Fane trails, no State Trail Pass is needed to ride here.

trails.name: Switz Bike Park (Little Switzerland)
trails.parkName: Kettle Moraine State Forest - Northern Unit
trails.description:
9/1/24: Permanently Closed

Two lifts service multiple trails ranging from beginner to expert rated.

trails.name: Vahtera 1
trails.description: Vahtera 1 is a small loop through beautiful forest and around a lake at Copper Falls State Park. It's a great option if you want to get in a little biking on a trip there.

trails.name: Copper Falls State Park
trails.description: Copper Falls has two one-way mountain bike trails (used for skiing in winter). Heading east from the North Camp area is the Vahtera Trail and heading west from the North Camp area is the Takesson Trail. Bicycling is allowed only on the designated bike trails.

trails.name: Takesson Trail
trails.description: Takesson Trail is a nice ski trail loop in Copper Falls State Park. There may not be much technical value to the trail, but at least the hilly terrain can give you a run for your money and scenic views of the Bad River accompany you for the first half!

trails.name: Loon Lake Access Trail
trails.description: Loon Lake Access Trail is a tiny connector linking Copper Falls State Park's campground to the North Country Trail.

trails.name: Easy Way Out Trail
trails.description: Easy Way Out Trail is a small connector if you decide you're not up for the whole Takesson Loop

trails.name: West Ridge
trails.description: West Ridge is a brutal trail. Steep, technical climbs are immediately followed by steep, rooty descents. That process is repeated a couple times without stop. If you can master it, though, there's not a feeling like it in the world.

trails.name: Connector Trail
trails.description: A small connector crossing the High School's property.

trails.name: Gandy Dancer
trails.description:
According to the Wisconsin DNR, "This 98-mile interstate trail crosses into Minnesota and then back again into Wisconsin on its way from St. Croix Falls to its connection with the Saunders State Trail just south of Superior. In Wisconsin, the trail is maintained and managed by Polk, Burnett and Douglas counties. The Minnesota DNR manages the section of the Gandy Dancer trail in Minnesota.
Built on a former railroad corridor, the trail is named for the work crews who laid the railroad tracks. The crews used tools made by the Gandy Tool Company of Chicago. The crews were known to work by keeping their voices and the movement of their feet and tools in harmony. This manner of work led the crews to become known as "Gandy Dancers."

The level grade and limestone surface make this trail suitable for bicyclists, walkers and joggers. A state trail pass is required for bicycling. You can buy annual and daily passes from designated vendors along the trail or at the Polk and Burnett County tourism centers."

http://dnr.wi.gov/topic/parks/name/gandydancer/

trails.name: Woolly Trails
trails.description: The St. Croix Falls Woolly Trails have something for EVERY level of rider.  One can start out riding the grass, limestone, or even black top bike trails.  For more advanced riders, the single track and sections of double track will challenge any rider with challenging terrain, tight corners, rocky sections, and log piles.

trails.name: Interconnect Trail
trails.description: Interconnect Trail is an easy-going trail connecting the Woolly Bike Club property to the technical West Ridge Trail.

trails.name: Big Oak
trails.description: Big Oak is a tight, twisty trail connecting the trail system's main parking lot with the Gandy Dancer Trail. It generally climbs, descends, and then climbs a decent bit again. Expect some tight berms and cool features to make this an awesome ride!

trails.name: Lower Meadow
trails.description: Lower Meadow is a singletrack/doubletrack that harbors no technical elements and generally climbs. It mostly just serves as an unpaved way to get to the northern trails of the Woolly system.

trails.name: Riegel Park Interconnect
trails.description: The Riegel Park Interconnect is a small singletrack connecting the Lower Glen and Riegel Park trails.

trails.name: South Riegel Park Connector
trails.description: The South Riegel Park Connector is a short trail used to get from Lower Meadow to the start of the Riegel Park Loop,Wissahickson, or the Gandy Dancer Trail. It can also be used to complete the Riegel Park Loop.

trails.name: Rock Garden
trails.description: Rock Garden is a small trail jutting off of the Riegel Park Trail that will give any rider a run for their money. To complete it, riders will have to navigate an long, awkward, and slow rock garden that takes focus but can be done. Good Luck!

trails.name: Wissahickon Trail
trails.description: Wissahickon Trail is a super fast, flowy segment of the Woolly Trail System. Expect twisty, hilly trail through pretty old second-growth forest.

trails.name: Erratic Rock
trails.description: The relatively new Erratic Rock Trail is a mostly buff ride  punctuated by berms and rollers. There is a little bit of a climb in the beginning, but that is made up for by the awesome descent back down at the end. Enjoy!

trails.name: [Private] Snowkraft Orchard Loop
trails.description: [Private trail] The Orchard section maintains an uphill/downhill pattern in a relatively open area. There are large berms on some of the downhill turns which makes it great for maintaining speed. There are some mounds to make it even more exciting with a chance to get some air. There are also some steep uphill sections which require some effort, but you can relieve yourself when you go back down.

trails.name: [Private] Snowkraft Singletrack Loop
trails.description: [Private trail] This singletrack trail quickly works into a hardwood forest then into groves of pine before working back into the hardwood trees. It's pretty smooth, with minimal roots or obstacles, as it twists and turns about through short rolling grades. It does intersect a lot of doubletrack trails, so just be on the lookout of where the singletrack will continue on the other side. Check Snowkraft's Facebook page for details on weekly evening rides.

trails.name: Black Diamond Loop
trails.description:
A short loop of technical trail including rocky ridges, tight corners, and steeper slopes along with a few log skinnies.
On the east side of the park is a beginner/intermediate short course, Old Fang Short Course, which flows along the hillside suiting any rider at any experience level.

trails.name: Old Fang Short Course - Big Hill Park
trails.description: From the parking stalls there is 1 loop directly to the west, about 30 yards marked with a black diamond. It runs counter-clockwise. The east loop is about 50 yards directly east of the parking stalls, hugging the southern border of the park. It is also marked.

trails.name: Potawatomi State Park
trails.description: About eight miles of off-road bike trails wind through the park. Parking for the trails is available in Parking Lot 1 near the picnic areas along the shoreline. Visitors can also bike on any of the park's roads.

trails.name: Ahnapee State Trail
trails.description: LocationFrom downtown Sturgeon Bay, this 46-mile, county-operated trail winds south along the beautiful Ahnapee and Kewaunee rivers to Algoma, Casco, Luxemburg and Kewaunee, passing by a mixture of evergreen glades, farmland, prairies and wooded areas teeming with wildlife and native wildflowers.

trails.name: Willow River State Park
trails.description: First 3.5 miles open October 9, 2021. Supported in part by Willow Kinni Mountain Bike Club. Up to 25 miles of trail planned to be constructed over the next three years.

trails.name: Birkmose Bluff
trails.description: Multiple loops of single track winding through the woods at Birkmose with views of the St.Croix River. Very difficult climbs along with steep rooty downhills. Also includes 2 downhill trails across Coulee Road. The trails across the road are on private property so be respectful and help keep the trails clean. All trails see heavy foot traffic so be aware and watch for pedestrians. Trails are still expanding so work on them is greatly appreciated.

trails.name: Whitetail Ridge
trails.description: The trail is a one-way. You enter on what seems to be an old fire road and there is a sign "Hooked" and points left, this is the start of the trail. The trail has some nice climbs with some tight spots and tough roots to navigate trough. There are some nicely place rock piles. The bridges on the trail almost look like professionally engineered items. Rumor has it, the club that built it is adding a teeter and other items

trails.name: Black Loop
trails.description: If the main loop is too tame, the Black Loop will definitely provide the challenge you're looking for. Besides the punchy climbs and steep descents, riders also have to deal with plenty of roots and rocks on off-camber trail. Good luck!

trails.name: Pokegama
trails.description: It's an out and back. There is a road you can take back to the lot. Some bridge crossings. Some spots aren't even dirt. This is a easy begginer trail. Helps you get  ready for the larger trail systems in the area.

trails.name: Spirit Mountain Bike Park
trails.description:
Two brand new downhill runs (opening spring 2013).

Gravity Trails:
Candyland: is a 1.5 mile beginner/ intermediate level downhill flow trail featuring large berms, medium and small sized table tops, and hip jumps. All features on Candyland are roll-able, making it an ideal trail to learn on, and perfect for gravity-based mountain biking skills.
Smorgasbord: is a 1 mile intermediate level freeride/ downhill mountain bike trail featuring large berms, medium size jumps, a drop, and rock gardens. Several features on Smorgasbord are mandatory, including small 3-4 foot gaps, and a 5-foot drop.
Happy Camper: is an easier downhill trail with features including small jumps, berms, and rollers.  This trail is perfect for beginners who are just learning downhill skills, but is also a fun trip for an expert rider.  "Happy Camper" is a directional trail, which means that when the chairlift is running it is signed as a DOWNHILL ONLY trail.  When the chairlift is not running, it is used as an UPHILL ONLY climbing trail.  By offering this uphill climbing option, you now have access to our awesome trails all the time!  When the chairlift isn't running, you just have to work a little harder for it.  *Please note that we do not have Bike Patrol on duty when the chairlift isn't running so please use extra caution and be careful on the trails.
Blaster: is a more difficult downhill single-track trail with features including lots of rocks, roots, and very little dirt.  This trail gets very steep in areas and is a true test of your downhill riding abilities.  Experienced riders only!
 
Spirit Mountain has been working on developing some downhill mountain bike trails over the past year in accordance with our Master Plan.  Cyclists will be able to ride the trails down the mountain and take the NEW "Spirit Express II" Chairlift back up to the top with their bikes in time for Memorial Day Weekend 2013.  The new flow trail will begin at the Spirit Mountain Adventure Park and end approximately 500 feet below, and a mile later, at the NEW Grand Avenue Chalet.  The site of the new flow trail was home to a Flow Trail School hosted by IMBA (International Mountain Bicycling Association) and COGGS (Cyclists of Gitchee Gumee Shores) in September 2012.  About 30 people from around the country attended the school to learn skills and techniques for building these types of trails.  The school was led by Aaron Rogers, IMBA Midwest Trail Specialist, who has officially declared this to be, "the best flow trail in the Midwest".  Additionally, Adam Sundberg, chairman of COGGS, says, "Everybody is blown away by how great the trail is looking.  It's so much fun, so creative, so well-done."

trails.name: Dreamland
trails.description:
Dreamland is a manicured intermediate flow trail. This sculpted jump line squeezes 21 jumps into 3,700 linear feet and 254 vertical feet of elevation loss. Flowy tabletops, most about 20 feet long (with some going as large as 28 feet), lead into massive berms to keep the speed high and flow alive.

<!-- wp:paragraph --> <!-- /wp:paragraph --> <!-- wp:paragraph --> <!-- /wp:paragraph -->

Dreamland was built with two main concepts in mind: progression and trail speed. "We were missing this aspect of progression," said Jon Regenold, Director of Resort Services for Spirit Mountain Recreation Area. He said that Spirit didn't need "a trail that you have to really dial in and figure out every single jump." Rather, they wanted "a trail that you can trust the builder and then a trail [where] you can enhance your riding. If you are only a green looking to be a blue, or blue looking to be a black jumper, you've got that ability to step it up and work on it."

trails.name: Nine Mile
trails.description:
A combination of Mountain Biking singletrack/snowshoe and XC ski trails.  This trail has a little bit of everything with 18.3 miles of wide open XC-ski two track that can be dirt road hammer fests or just a nice easy green trail for beginners.  The 13.5 mile single track system was heavily updated in 2014/2015 by the local IMBA Chapter, CWOCC.  All single track is now interconnected with the trailhead near the south (front) end of the chalet where you can find The Pines or Jim's Trail.  The single track system broken down into three loop clusters: the East Loops, across Red Bud Road, are some of the oldest trail.  Hand built and generally rooty and rugged at times but also flow well.  Yin/Yang loop is a good intermediate trail with Stone Soup being quite rocky and rugged advanced trail.  The West Loop is a mix of new school/old school trail.  All intermediate level trail the newest sections of Up Nort, Outbound and a chunk of Chainsmoker feature lots of berms and rollers for great flow.  Root Canal, Icky Thump, half of Chainsmoker maintain the older hand built feel.  The South Loop or advanced loop is accessed off the west end of Outbound.  Here you'll be treated to a lot of rooty and rocky trail.  The most challenging sections being Flower, Stinger, Ho Chi Minh, K-bypass and White Knuckle, however, there is one touch of bermed flowy goodness on the descent of Ho Chi Minh.  This loop rides well in the counter clockwise direction starting with Flower and ending with White Knuckle.  All trails are two way so there are lots of options for riding.

Nine Mile County Forest is located only about 5 miles from the city of Wausau.  The trail costs $4.00 to ride and $25.00 for an annual pass.  All trail fees are allocated back towards the operation of Nine Mile recreation.  The trails are open for riding from May 1st (conditions dependent) until October 15th.  Also be aware that Nine Mile is a managed forest unit, hunting occurs early and late in the season and there are often logging operations that could affect trail access.

trails.name: Sunnyvale County Park
trails.description: This winter only trail system is now closed and will no longer be maintained in the future. Repeated flooding conditions rendered this trail difficult to maintain through the winter season.

trails.name: The Pines
trails.description: The Pines can be combined with Jim's Trail to create a great loop for the kids. On a gradual climb, its non-technical tread winds through a pine forest (hence its name). It is also the trail used to access the West Loop in the counter-clockwise direction.

trails.name: Yin
trails.description: Yin is one half of the Yin & Yang loop. Expect tight, twisty trail that balances rocks and roots with fast flow.

trails.name: Up Nort
trails.description: Up Nort is one of the newest additions to Nine Mile. With the help of berms and rollers, it descents into a small valley and then climbs back out. Overall, its twisty flow makes it one of the most fun trails at Nine Mile!

trails.name: Yang
trails.description: Yang, commonly used to create a loop with Yin, undulates through pine and hardwood forest on twisting singletrack. Expect some roots and rocks to spice up the otherwise flowy ride.

trails.name: Stone Soup
trails.description: Stone Soup is one of the most challenging trails at Nine Mile. As you wind through red pine and mixed hardwood forest, many rock (many of the "rocks" are much bigger than regular rocks, though) gardens are thrown at you. The sheer amount of stones is so large that there is little actually flow, making it hard to stitch the features together smoothly. Furthermore, the lack of downhill momentum doesn't help either. Basically, this is a little slice of heaven for those who love low-speed rock gardens with no obvious way to clear them.

trails.name: Icky Thump
trails.description: A mostly flat trail with a few technical roots and rocks interspersed throughout, Icky Thump is a fast ride through an impressive stand of pines used to get to Up Nort.

trails.name: East Loop Connector
trails.description: East Loop Connector is a short singletrack linking the West Loop (Yin and Yang) to the East Loop.

trails.name: Outbound
trails.description: From Up Nort, the northern portion is mostly old school singletrack. You'll run into a few roots and rocks along the way, but that portion is mostly a fast and straight run towards the Advanced Loop Connector. However, once you pass the connector and go onto the southern portion, the trail completely changes. It morphs into a new school flow trail gradually making its way up and down the surrounding hills via bermed turns, fun rollers, and tacky dirt. Overall, Outbound provides a great taste of some of Wisconsin's best singletrack from both schools of trail design.

trails.name: Chain Smoker
trails.description: Chain Smoker offers a little bit of everything. In the beginning, old school singletrack with a few good roots dominates the ride as you pass through some pines. However, once you make it to the top, wide, bermed corners characterize the comparatively flowy trail.

trails.name: White Knuckle
trails.description: White Knuckle is the traditional end of the Nine Mile Advanced Loop (although it could also be the beginning). It starts (from south to north) on smooth, fast trail descending from a ridge through forest. Then, right before the end, riders are treated to a long, uninterrupted section of roots and rocks that will certainly given you white knuckles.

trails.name: Advanced Loop Connector
trails.description: A short connector between Outbound and Flower.

trails.name: Bear Bones
trails.description: If the Advanced Loop is kicking your butt, you'll appreciate Bear Bones. All it is is a smooth, flat(ish) fire road that has faded into singletrack.

trails.name: Flower
trails.description: Flower is one of Nine Mile's classics. Its rocky, rooty tread meanders up through old-growth forest and aspen groves before bombing down the hill on the other side. If you manage to get there during spring, you'll get the extra treat of flowers surrounding the trail on the forest floor.

trails.name: Ho Chi Minh
trails.description: The Ho Chi Minh trail has quite the variety because it has been continually added to for awhile. Some sections are wide open, fast, and rocky while others are beautifully bermed and sculpted. Add in the fact that it has one of the only major descents in the system, and it becomes a must-do.

trails.name: Super G
trails.description: Super G is a wide and open climb on the Advanced Loop. The first portion was built on a logging road and largely lacks technical trail features, so riders can punch it as fast or as slow as they like. Once you reach an aspen stand, the trail tightens up a little, but with some good turning technique, riders can still hammer their way to Stinger.

trails.name: Stinger
trails.description: Stinger is probably the most technical trail at Nine Mile. As riders gradually descent, they'll meet rock garden after rock garden after rock garden, etc, etc. Enjoy those challenging low-speed bits because before you know it, it'll be over.

trails.name: Barker-Stewart Island Interpretative Trail
trails.description: Barker-Stewart Island Interpretative Trail is a great option for getting the whole family riding in Wausau. Be sure to read the historical signs all along the doubletrack to get the full experience.

trails.name: Greenwood Hills Nordic Trails
trails.description:
Trails are winter time only use!  These are shared use winter nordic trails that run throughout the hilly terrain of Greenwood Hills Country Club golf course and private wooded property to the south of the course.  Trail width is approximately 8' so not singletrack but is still challenging terrain and fun to ride.  Bar & grill has great menu and selection of beer on tap.

Again, you have to purchase a winter country club membership to have access to the trails and clubhouse.

trails.name: Sylvan Hill Bike Park
trails.description:
One of a kind all encompassing bike park at Sylvan Hill.  Normally a tubing hill in the winter time is now a gravity oriented summer bike park built by Rock Solid Trail Contracting out of Copper Harbor, MI.  

Trail layout is a 1.3 mile long outer loop, downhill w/ some XC flow at the bottom and return climb.  Inside the main loop are three progressively harder downhill only runs ranging from .25 to .4 miles in length.  

Sylvan's Run outer loop downhill is relatively tame in difficulty but has lots of rock options on the side to spice things up.  Some nice flow along the lower hill with boardwalks and a view of Jim Moore Creek.

Intermediate downhill run, Bad Rabbit, has a series of tabletop jumps with  bermed corners.  Rollable for most but plenty of air can be had.

Advanced downhill run, Twisted Oak, has a 2-3' rock lip jump at the entry you must clear to ride.  Tabletop's are much larger with raised lips that encourage you to go faster to clear them properly.

Expert downhill run, Fish Hook, has a 5-6' rock lip gap jump you must clear to enter the trail.  All jumps require a lot more speed to clear.

At the top of the park is a large pump track and small skill area for added fun.

trails.name: Hartman Creek State Park
trails.description: There are about 12 miles of off-road biking trails in the park which are combination hiking/biking segments. A 6-mile segment is all singletrack and was completed by a local bike club, Cronies. These trails are not paved. Bikers age 16 and older must have a daily or annual state trail pass to use trails within the park.

trails.name: Spruce Trail
trails.description: Spruce Trail is a small singletrack trail running along the banks of the Fisher River on Brunet Island. This would be a great addition to a larger family-oriented ride around the state park.

trails.name: Pine Trail
trails.description: Pine Trail is a small, easy singletrack on Brunet Island through a pine plantation. This is a great route to get around the island with kids.

trails.name: Tiber Trail
trails.description: Tiber Trail is an easy ride from the picnic area to the campground at Brunet Island State Park. Although it's short, riders are treated to beautiful hemlock and aspens along the way. Combining it with the other trails on the island could create a nice loop to do with kids.

trails.name: Governor Dodge State Park
trails.description:
Fast doubletrack with lots of hills. Mostly grassy mowed trail, some roots, rocks gravel and sand. A large loop and a small loop that form a figure 8. My wife loves this trail because it offers a good aerobic workout without being too technically challenging. Good for novices, but they may end up walking up some of the hills.

WI State Park pass required. WI State Trail pass required.
